title: Omicron: What We Know About the New Coronavirus Variant
content: Intense research into the new coronavirus variant first identified in southern Africa has just begun. World leaders have urged people not to panic — and to get vaccinated, if they can.

title: He Never Touched the Murder Weapon. Alabama Sentenced Him to Die.
content: Nathaniel Woods was unarmed when three Birmingham police officers were fatally shot by someone else in 2004. But Woods, a Black man, was convicted of capital murder for his role in the deaths of the three white officers.

more_info.byline: By Dan Barry and Abby Ellin

title: On Syria’s Ruins, a Drug Empire Flourishes
content: Powerful associates of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, are making and selling captagon, an illegal amphetamine, creating a new narcostate on the Mediterranean.

more_info.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

title: After Success in Seating Federal Judges, Biden Hits Resistance
content: Senate Democrats vow to keep pressing forward with nominees, but they may face obstacles in states represented by Republicans.

title: Critical Moment for Roe, and the Supreme Court’s Legitimacy
content: As justices consider Mississippi’s restrictive abortion law, scholars debate what a reversal of Roe v. Wade would mean for the court’s credibility.

title: Voting Battles of 2022 Take Shape as G.O.P. Crafts New Election Bills
content: Republicans plan to carry their push to reshape the nation’s electoral system into next year, with Democrats vowing to oppose them but holding few options in G.O.P.-led states.

title: CNN Fires Chris Cuomo Amid Inquiry Into His Efforts to Aid His Brother
content: The network said it had “terminated him, effective immediately,” a move that came days after a lawyer for a former colleague accused the host of sexual misconduct.

more_info.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Jodi Kantor

title: Christmas Tree Questions? Ask the Mayor of Rockefeller Center.
content: For two decades, Correll Jones has been the man to ask about New York’s most famous tree — and where to find the public bathrooms.

title: The Weekender
content: A climbing award that may be a winner’s last. Also in this edition: the great “West Side Story” debate, and a look at luxury senior housing.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, December 3, 2021
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Condé Nast Knows Faded Glory Is Not in Style
content: Anna Wintour is the embodiment of the glory days of the magazine dynasty. Now she is pitching its global, digital future.

title: You Should Be Afraid of the Next ‘Lab Leak’
content: Covid might not have come out of a medical research lab, but it raises some urgent questions about how those facilities operate.

title: Our Most Popular Recipes of 2021
content: A countdown of the delicious dishes our readers viewed the most this year.

title: Who Will Hold Prosecutors Accountable?
content: The Justice Department’s Office of Professional Responsibility needs an overhaul.

title: Where the Pro-Choice Movement Went Wrong
content: How abortion-rights groups failed to stop the erosion of Roe v. Wade.

title: What Biden Isn’t Saying About Trump’s Positive Covid Test
content: The former president’s reckless behavior deserves more attention.

title: Chris Cuomo Has a Funny Idea About What Doing His Job Means
content: Reporting on the suspension of a brotherly TV host.

title: Biden Can Do Better on Covid
content: The administration has been a victim of events. But it has also cooperated in its own victimization.

title: Josh Hawley and the Republican Obsession With Manliness
content: The Missouri senator is tapping into something real — a widespread, politically potent anxiety about young men that is already helping the right.

title: The Metaverse Is Coming, and the World Is Not Ready for It
content: The geopolitical consequences may be radical.

title: I Was the Governor of Montana. My Fellow Democrats, You Need to Get Out of the City More.
content: It’s time to ditch the grand ideological narratives and talk to voters about their real needs.

title: Wonking Out: Money Isn’t Everything
content: No, not even in macroeconomics.

title: Squares, Blocks, Cubes — What Is Happening in Silicon Valley?
content: Twitter’s new boss needs to boost the company’s value, or someone else will.

title: For Parents, Omicron Is Another Waiting Game
content: A worrisome week in news.

title: Why the Fed Chair Won’t Call Inflation ‘Transitory’ Anymore
content: Jerome Powell has lost patience with the pace of the rebound in labor force participation.

title: Can a Michigan Football Game Make Me Happy Forever?
content: The euphoria of a big win, explained.

title: Behind Low Vaccination Rates Lurks a More Profound Social Weakness
content: Vaccine hesitancy reflects a transformation of people’s core beliefs about what we owe each other.

more_info.byline: By Anita Sreedhar and Anand Gopal

title: A Way to Break the Cycle of Poverty
content: Intervening in children’s lives early can help break the cycle of intergenerational poverty.

title: The Supreme Court Should Reject Arizona’s Death Penalty Gambit
content: Two Arizona men who were appointed ineffective lawyers landed on death row. If Arizona has its way, the Supreme Court will close an already narrow avenue for relief.

title: Columbia University Student Dies in Stabbing Near Campus
content: The graduate student, Davide Giri, was fatally stabbed near the Manhattan campus on Thursday night. A man has been arrested and charged with murder, the police said.

more_info.byline: By Troy Closson and Lola Fadulu

title: Meet an Ecologist Who Works for God (and Against Lawns)
content: A Long Island couple say fighting climate change and protecting biodiversity starts at home. Or rather, right outside their suburban house.

more_info.byline: By Cara Buckley and Karsten Moran

title: Cognitive Rehab: One Patient’s Painstaking Path Through Long Covid Therapy
content: Samantha Lewis is relearning some basic aspects of her daily life after struggling with brain fog and other lingering symptoms for more than a year since being infected by the virus.

more_info.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alex Wroblewski

title: Stabbed 20 Times by Her Husband, She Now Fights Laws Favoring Abusers
content: Shira Isakov, once a little-known Israeli working in advertising, has become a national force in the struggle to combat domestic violence and change the legal landscape on parental rights.

title: A Slow-Motion Climate Disaster: The Spread of Barren Land
content: Brazil’s northeast, long a victim of droughts, is now effectively turning into a desert. The cause? Climate change and the landowners who are most affected.

more_info.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

title: Adele Returns, From Beyond Space and Time
content: Will we ever see a star who unites audiences like this British musician again?

title: Recipe Plagiarism and Buying a High School: The Week in Narrated Articles
content: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

title: Explore the Sound of Activism With Tom Morello
content: Songs and social movements often go hand in hand. What music defines our politically charged times? Join a virtual event on Dec. 15.

title: Facing Economic Collapse, Afghanistan Is Gripped by Starvation
content: An estimated 22.8 million people — more than half the country’s population — are expected to face potentially life-threatening food insecurity this winter. Many are already on the brink of catastrophe.

org_facet: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

title: Three Months After Hurricane Ida, Residents Are Still Waiting for FEMA Housing
content: As storms and fires become more severe, disaster housing policy has failed to keep up, leaving people displaced for months on end.

more_info.byline: By Sophie Kasakove and Katy Reckdahl

title: When the Biggest Spenders Aren’t Coming Back Any Time Soon
content: Even before Omicron’s arrival, China was discouraging its citizens from traveling abroad. That has had a huge impact on global tourism.

more_info.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee, Elisabetta Povoledo, Muktita Suhartono and Léontine Gallois
geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

title: Fatalities Reported After Military Truck Rams Protesters in Myanmar
content: Witnesses said soldiers also fired into the crowd and kicked wounded demonstrators, the latest in a series of confrontations in which the military’s behavior has infuriated citizens.

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

title: To Counter China, Austin Vows to Shore Up Alliances With Others in Region
content: “America is a Pacific power,” the defense secretary said as he laid out a strategy to block efforts by China to dominate the region.

title: Michigan Rolls to a Playoff Spot With Big Ten Title
content: The Wolverines followed up a season-defining win over Ohio State with an easy victory over Iowa to win the conference championship.

title: Substack Expands Food Newsletters With Ruth Reichl and Others
content: The former restaurant critic and Gourmet editor is joining a cadre of chefs and authors enlisted to expand the platform’s culinary content.

title: Alabama Picks Apart Georgia, Setting Course for Another Playoff
content: No. 3 Alabama, the reigning national champion, fell behind early. Then it pounded the country’s best defense to run away with the Southeastern Conference championship.

title: Don Demeter, a Dodger Star of the Future Who Wasn’t, Dies at 86
content: Groomed to replace Duke Snider, he broke his wrist in 1960 and never lived up to expectations. But he had a fine career with four other teams.

title: Our 8 Favorite Books in 2021 for Healthy Living
content: This year’s Well Book List includes advice on how to change behavior, lower anxiety, cope with hardship and heal with poetry.

title: Overcoming Motherhood Imposter Syndrome
content: Casey Wilson learned to trust her parenting instincts after her son received a surprise diagnosis.

title: New Hope for Migraine Sufferers
content: There are now a number of medications that may prevent or alleviate migraines, as well as a wearable nerve-stimulating device that can be activated by a smartphone.

title: Older Singles Have Found a New Way to Partner Up: Living Apart
content: Fearing that a romantic attachment in later life will lead to full-time caregiving, many couples are choosing commitment without sharing a home.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Poop, Pie and a Heart-Healthy Diet
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

title: Magritte, Surrealism and the Pipe That Is Not a Pipe
content: Alex Danchev’s biography of René Magritte portrays a subversive artist who had no interest in bohemian life.

title: On Japan’s Pacific Coast, an Artist Communes With Nature
content: At his retreat near Isumi, Kazunori Hamana creates humble yet imposing ceramic vessels that evoke the world around him.

more_info.byline: By Hannah Kirshner and Ben Richards

title: Baby Tate Turns Hate Into Positivity
content: The rapper was shamed for a revealing outfit at Afropunk Atlanta. But that’s not stopping her.

title: Paul Verhoeven Has Made a Film About a Lesbian Nun. Jesus Is Next.
content: The Dutch filmmaker explains what his new movie, based on a real 17th-century sister, has in common with “Showgirls” and “Basic Instinct.”

title: How Joaquin Phoenix Handles Parenting in ‘C’mon C’mon’
content: The writer and director Mike Mills narrates a sequence from his film featuring Phoenix and Woody Norman.
